Name: ji xue teng
Biological: Millettia dielsiana Harms (香花岩豆藤, 山雞血藤)
Spatholobus suberectus Dunn (密花豆屬密花豆)
Kadsura interior A.C. Smith (内南五味子)
Kadsura heteroclita (Roxb.) Craib (異形南五味子)

Maladies Treated: Patterns due to blood deficiency or blood stasis
Leukopenia (white blood cell count decrease): ji xue teng syrup reported certain efficacy
Low platelet count: ji xue teng syrup is being used and getting some result
Rheumatoid arthritis, especially chronic patients with blood deficiency and blood stasis pattern
Rheumatic arthralgia with numbness of hands and feet
Sequelae of stroke with limb paralysis; to be combined with herbs that benefit qi, nourish blood, invigorate blood, and open the collaterals
Blood deficiency with sallow complexion; to be combined with qi and blood tonics
Medical Function: Invigorates blood and supplements blood; suitable for blood stasis and blood deficiency patterns
Regulates menstruation in cases with blood deficiency or blood stasis where the menstrual flow is not smooth
Samples of Formulae:
For blood stasis and to regulate menses: Ji Xue Teng (Diel's millettia / Spatholobus suberectus) + Hong Hua (Safflower) + Chuan Xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong rhizome) + Xiang Fu (Cyperus rhizome); indicated to invigorate blood, transform stasis, and regulate menstruation.

For blood deficiency and to regulate menses: Ji Xue Teng (Diel's millettia / Spatholobus suberectus) + Shu Di Huang (Prepared rehmannia root) + Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis root); indicated to nourish blood and regulate menstruation.
Contraindications: Use with care in patterns of yinxu with fire (陰虛火旺).
Research:
Decoction of Millettia dielsiana (山雞血藤) or Spatholobus suberectus (密花豆) improved experimentally induced anemia in rabbits and showed anti-inflammatory effects (animal experiment).

Small doses enhanced rhythmic uterine contractions of rabbits; larger doses produced stronger contractions. Pregnant uteri were more sensitive (animal experiment).

Decoction of Millettia dielsiana (山雞血藤) inhibited Staphylococcus aureus in vitro.

Enhanced macrophage function and improved immune function (experimental observation).

In vitro, inhibited platelet aggregation induced by adenosine diphosphate or collagen; lowered vascular resistance; increased coronary artery blood flow of isolated heart preparations and femoral artery blood flow (in vitro/isolated organ experiments).

Improved reduced white blood cell counts in laboratory mice caused by cyclophosphamide (環磷醯胺) (animal experiment).

Lowered total cholesterol and increased high-density cholesterol in quails (animal experiment); exhibited cardiac inhibitory and blood pressure–lowering effects.

Modern Research: Spatholobus suberectus 密花豆 — see Medical function on other items; remaining details are covered under pharmacology above.

Name: xu chang qing
徐長卿
Other: zhu ye xi xin 竹葉細辛

Geography: Distributed in most part of China.
Maladies Treated: Traumatic injury swelling and pain (跌打腫痛)
Medical Function: Arresting pain; stopping itching; reducing swelling.
Qufeng (dispelling wind) and stopping pain; detoxification and reducing swelling; warming the meridian and activating the collaterals. [1]
Samples of Formulae:
For poisonous snake bite: Xu Chang Qing [Cynanchum paniculatum root] with Ban Bian Lian [Lobelia chinensis]; boil with water. Take orally and/or apply externally. [1]

For eczema, hives, contact dermatitis, tinea: Xu Chang Qing 6–12 g each time; prepare as decoction for oral use and/or external wash; can also be prepared as injections. Treated 36 cases: 24 healed, 8 improved, 4 ineffective. [1]
Contraindications: Use with care if the patient is weak. [1]
Research:
Sedation: Paeonol (牡丹酚) has a sedative effect. [2]

Heart rate lowering and blood pressure–lowering effects. [2]

Lipid-lowering effect. [2]

Smooth muscle relaxation. [2]

Antibacterial effect: Cynanchum whole-plant decoction at 1:4 shows inhibition against Shigella (福氏痢疾杆菌) and Salmonella typhi (傷寒杆菌); at 1:2 shows inhibition against Pseudomonas aeruginosa (綠膿杆菌), Escherichia coli (大腸杆菌), and Staphylococcus aureus (金色葡萄球菌). Paeonol in vitro: at 1:15000 shows inhibition against Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis (枯草杆菌); at 1:2000 shows inhibition against Staphylococcus aureus. [2]

Paeonol anti-tumor effect. [3]

The ethanol extract of Xu Chang Qing prevented apoptosis in a neuron cell model and reduced the apoptosis rate in brain tissue after herpes simplex virus encephalitis in lab mice. [5]

Whole herb: Substances similar to deacylmetaplexigenin (和去酰蘿甙元極為相似的物質)
Other reports: C21 deformed steroidal glycosides compounds (C21變形甾甙類化合物)
Glaucogenin D (由芫花葉白前甙元D)
Cynapanoside A, B, C (不同糖鏈成的徐長卿甙A，B，C)
D-erythritol (phycitol, meso-erythritol, L-erythritol, erythrit) (D-赤絲草醇)

Geography: China: south of the Yangtze River; middle and lower reaches of the Yellow River; coastal regions; southwest and south China provinces and regions
Maladies Treated: Pediatric malnutrition/infantile malnutrition (小兒疳積) (fresh herb with pig liver, internal)
Uterine bleeding (fresh herb juice or decoction, internal)
Traumatic bleeding (fresh herb smashed with a little sugar, topical)
Eczema (external wash or juice applied topically)
Snake bites (with ban bian lian and da qing ye; internal)
Lack of mother's milk (乳汁不足) (fresh 15–30 g or dried 6–9 g, decocted with fish; internal)
Infantile bloating, testicular enlargement (fresh herb, decoction; internal)
Necrosis fistula/osteomyelitic sinus (附骨疽瘘管) (with gou er cha rhizome; simmered with wine and water; internal)
Medical Function: Clears heat and toxin (清熱解毒)
Dosage: Daily dosage: 15–30 g (0.5–1 liang). External use: appropriate amount; use fresh herb, smash and apply to affected area.
Samples of Formulae:
Enteritis, diarrhea, vomiting blood, nose bleeding, blood in the stool, cough, asthma: dried tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) 30–60 g. Decoction, taken orally. Source: Guangzhou armed forces "Chinese Herbal Medicine Handbook".
Dermatitis, eczema: use tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) decoction as an external wash. Source: Guangzhou armed forces "Chinese Herbal Medicine Handbook".
Traumatic bleeding: fresh tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) appropriate amount with a little sugar. Smash and apply topically.
Snake bites: tie xian cai (Acalypha australis), ban bian lian (Lobelia chinensis), da qing ye (Isatis leaf) 30 g each. Decoction, taken orally. Source: "Jiangxi Herbs".
Traumatic injuries/wounds: xue jian chou (tie xian cai) (Acalypha australis) 18–30 g (six qian to one liang). Decoction, taken orally. Source: "Shanghai Chinese Herbal Medicine".
Infantile malnutrition: fresh tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) 30–60 g. Make soup with pig liver and take orally. Source: "Zhejiang Folk Commonly Used Herbs".
Infantile bloating, testicular enlargement: fresh tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) 30–60 g. Decoction, taken orally. Source: "Zhejiang Folk Commonly Used Herbs".
Uterine bleeding: fresh tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) 30–60 g. Smash to make juice or decoct; take orally. Source: "Northeast Chinese Herbal Medicine Handbook".
Lack of mother's milk: fresh tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) 15–30 g, or dried herb 6–9 g. Decoct with fish and take orally. Source: "Northeast Chinese Herbal Medicine Handbook".
Scarlet fever rash and eczema: deng zhan wo (tie xian cai) (Acalypha australis) smash, extract juice, and apply externally. Source: "Guizhou medicine".
Asthma or coughing up blood: deng zhan wo (tie xian cai) (Acalypha australis) 60 g (two liang). Decoct and take orally. Source: "Guizhou medicine".
Necrosis fistula (附骨疽瘘管): dried tie xian cai (Acalypha australis) 60–90 g, dried gou er cha (Berchemia rhizome) 60 g. Simmer with wine and water; take orally. Source: "Fujian Chinese Herbal Medicine".
Contraindications: Do not use during pregnancy. Those who are old or weak with qi deficiency should use less. Source: 《泉州本草》.
Research:
In vitro, tie xian cai decoction showed antibacterial activity against several common Shigella species, especially Shigella dysenteriae (2-fold dilution method). At a dilution of 1:256, it exhibited not only bacteriostatic but also bactericidal effects. Activity against Shigella flexneri and Shigella boydii (Freund) was weaker, and activity against Shigella sonnei was the weakest. Tablets made from tie xian cai also showed anti-Shigella effects in vitro.
In vitro, a 50% tie xian cai decoction exhibited varying degrees of inhibitory effects on Staphylococcus aureus, Vibrio cholerae, Bacillus anthracis, and Shigella flexneri (agar plate method). Antibacterial constituents are present in the roots, stems, and leaves; the antibacterial potency appears to differ among plant parts and target bacteria. An alcohol extract of tie xian cai also showed antibacterial activity.

Maladies Treated: Hepatitis with jaundice: fresh pandan leaves (leaf) 60 g used with xi shu guo (noni fruit) 30 g and sabah snake grass (you dun cao) 30 g; boiled with water and taken orally. Source: Hulu.com, Section of Experienced Formulae.
Medical Function: Blackening hair: washing hair with pandan leaf decoction combined with juice of ripe noni fruit; used three times per week until results are seen.
Dosage:
Oral: decoction, 15–30 g dried leaf; fresh herb 60–120 g. Alternatively, squeeze for juice and mix with honey and take orally, or make into juice and gargle.

External: appropriate amount; wash, smash and apply topically, or decoct to wash affected areas, or sun-dry and powder for dressing, or prepare as topical ointment or cream for application to affected areas.
Samples of Formulae:
Hepatitis with jaundice: xi shu guo (noni fruit) 30 g, you dun cao (sabah snake grass) 30 g, fresh pandan leaves 60 g. Boil with water and take orally. Source: Hulu.com, Section of Experienced Formulae. Note: See Possible Toxicity and Cautions.

Blacken hair: pandan leaves (as many as 7 leaves), washed and cut into pieces. Boil with 1 liter of water until the color turns green. Let the decoction sit overnight. The next morning, squeeze juice from 3 ripe xi shu guo (noni fruit). Mix the noni juice with the pandan leaf decoction prepared earlier. Use the mixture to wash hair. Apply 3 times per week until hair turns black. Source: Indonesian Ministry of Agriculture website [4].
Contraindications:
Leaves of some Pandanus species are known to contain calcium oxalate crystals; may be harmful to individuals with decreased kidney function.

Possible liver toxicity of noni fruit: The Panel on Dietetic Products, Nutrition and Allergies of the European Food Safety Authority concluded that “Morinda citrifolia (Noni) fruit puree and concentrate as novel food ingredients” under the specified conditions are considered safe for the general population. However, the Panel considers that the increasing number of case reports might indicate that some individuals have particular sensitivity for hepatotoxic effects to noni fruit products. Noni fruit (and its products) are listed by the U.S. State Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as toxic items. Reports indicate: (1) those with renal dysfunction had higher chance for renal damage; (2) more cases of acute hepatitis have been reported after consumption of noni products.
Research:
Pandanus amaryllifolius contains lectin with anti-human viruses including herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) and influenza virus (H1N1). [2]

P. amaryllifolius ethanol extract induced apoptosis in vitro on the hormone-independent breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231. [1]

Leaf extract significantly retarded oil oxidation and deterioration.
Chemical Ingredients: Leaves (some Pandanus species): calcium oxalate crystals

Chao bai shao (stir-fried bai shao): pixu (spleen deficient) with abdominal pain and diarrhea.
Jiu bai shao (rice wine treated bai shao): liver overactive and blood deficient with blood stasis.
Cu bai shao (vinegar treated bai shao): arresting pain in the liver; gan ji shi rou (肝急失柔).
Medical Function: Removing blood stasis (bai shao; chi shao stronger).
Mild analgesic by addressing blood stasis.
Dilates peripheral blood vessels; lowers peripheral resistance.
Neutralizes the carcinogenic effect of aflatoxins.
Chi shao: rids gas from stomach and intestine.
Samples of Formulae:
For common cold and flu: gui zhi tang (Cinnamon Twig Decoction), ma huang tang (Ephedra Decoction).
Formulas including shao yao: bai zhu shao yao san (Atractylodes and Peony Powder); dang gui jian zhong tang (Tangkuei Decoction for the Middle); dang gui shao yao san (Tangkuei and Peony Powder); gui zhi tang (Cinnamon Twig Decoction); ma huang tang (Ephedra Decoction); shi quan da bu tang (All-Inclusive Great Tonifying Decoction); si wu tang (Four-Substance Decoction); ren shen yang rong tang (Ginseng Nourishing Decoction); wan dai fang (Complete Belt Formula).
Contraindications:
Do not use raw bai shao in case of pain in abdomen or with diarrhea due to pixu (spleen deficient). Use chao bai shao (stir fried bai shao) instead.
Postpartum: do not use chi shao.
Research:
Protective effect: extract from bai shao and huang qi against liver injury induced by bacillus Calmette-Gu廨in and lipopolysaccharide in mice.
In vitro studies found inhibition of hepatitis B virus [3].
One of the active components, paeoniflorin, has been reported to be able to reverse or alleviate behavioral and cognitive impairments [4].
Antidepressant effect in animal models of depression; the action of Paeonia lactiflora may be mediated via the central monoaminergic neurotransmitter system [5].
The acute oral toxicity of aconitine in rats was significantly reduced by paeoniflorin [1].
Notes:
Bai shao is used for removing blood stasis and as a mild analgesic by addressing blood stasis.
Chi shao has a much stronger effect in removing blood stasis and is used more often than bai shao in traumatic injuries and blood clots.
Raw bai shao is used for lian yin ping gan (斂陰平肝), especially liver yang ascending and internal stirring of liver wind.
Chao bai shao (stir-fried) excels at nourishing blood and the liver; often used when the liver is exuberant and the spleen is deficient with pain and diarrhea.
Jiu bai shao (rice wine treated) tends toward nourishing blood and activating blood; most suitable for blood deficiency with cold congealing and blood stasis.
Cu bai shao (vinegar treated) enhances softening the liver and relieving pain; commonly used when the liver is urgent and loses softness (肝急失柔).

Roots contain: paeoni-lactone A, B, C (芍藥內酯)
Volatile oil (evaporating oil): 33 kinds of other alcohol and phenol compounds (及其他33種醇類和酚類成份)
